reasoning: The critique targets a key illustrative mechanism in section 3 (moral trade enabling near-best outcomes via a ‘split the cosmos’ deal) by arguing it is dynamically unstable due to incentives to defect and successor/identity problems after self-modification and copying. This matters to the essay’s conditional optimism about trade, but it doesn’t fully undercut the essay’s overall (already cautious) stance because trade is presented as one possible route contingent on institutions, enforcement, and absence of blockers; the essay also flags lock-in/threats/power concentration. The argument is moderately strong: dynamic inconsistency and renegotiation under changing agents are genuine obstacles that can shift equilibria toward preemptive conflict, though not inevitably (credible commitment mechanisms, mutual deterrence, or governance could partially address it). Most claims are directionally correct but somewhat overstated in universality (‘any local power center’ / ‘inevitably’ militarization). Clear, focused, with little filler.
title: Cosmic bargains are dynamically unstable under technological dominance and identity change
